name: CO2 Effects on Plant Mineral Concentrations
description: This meta-analysis investigates how elevated atmospheric CO2 affects mineral element concentrations in plants. The key hypothesis is that elevated CO2 causes a 'dilution effect' - plants grow larger but mineral uptake doesn't keep pace, resulting in lower mineral concentrations. Based on Loladze et al. 2014 (eLife 3:e02245).
primary_outcomes: Mineral element concentrations: N, P, K, Ca, Mg, Fe, Zn, Mn, Cu, S, B, Mo, Na, Cd, Cr, Ni, Pb, Se, Si, V, Al, Sr, Ba, Co, Cl
extraction_priorities: 1. CRITICAL: Extract EVERY ROW from tables - NO POOLING across cultivars, years, or treatments
2. If table has 20 rows, you should have ~20 observations. Count them!
3. Prioritize mineral concentration data over biomass data
4. Get variance (SE/SD) and sample size (n) for meta-analysis weighting
5. Record tissue type (grain vs leaf vs root) as it affects interpretation
6. Record the specific CO2 levels (ppm) for both control and treatment
tc_confusion_warnings: Watch for papers that report 'ambient' vs 'elevated' - ambient is control
Some papers report percentage of ambient - 100% = control, >100% = elevated
Water stress treatments (FWC levels) are NOT CO2 treatments
If effect is strongly positive (+50%), verify T/C assignment
AMF (mycorrhizal) treatments create factorial designs - extract both levels separately
